pages.text: Caturus is a genus of Amiiform bony fish that appeared in the Jurassic and disappeared in the Early Cretaceous. Quite widespread, the genus has been found in Europe, Asia, Africa, North and South America. The species C. giganteus has now been reassigned to Strobilodus

Variable in size, the largest species could grow up to 2 meters in length with a deeply lunate tail characteristic of fast swimming predators. Due to its huge stratigraphic range, spanning 120 million years, and differences in size and shape, Caturus was likely paraphyletic, meaning some of the animals we call Caturus today might've been something different.
